name: Warhammer® 40,000: Dawn of War® - Game of the Year Edition
description: Prepare yourself for the grim, dark future of the 41st millennium, where alien races battle mankind for galactic domination in a universe of unending war. Personalize your armies with a revolutionary unit customization tool that gives you the ability to choose your armies insignias, banners, squad colors and names.
minimum_requirements: Windows 2000/XP, 1.8 Ghz Intel Pentium III or equivalent AMD Athlon XP, 256 MB RAM, 4.5 GB free hard drive space, 32 MB DirectX 9.0c compatible AGP video card with Hardware Transformation and Lighting, 16-bit DirectX 9.0b compatible sound card, Mouse, Keyboard Recommended: 2.4 GHz Intel Pentium 4 or equivalent, 512 MB system RAM (required for 8-player multiplayer games), nVidia GeForce 3 or ATI Radeon 8500 or equivalent with 64 MB of Video RAM  Required for Multiplayer:  Internet: Cable modem, DSL modem, or 56.6 kbps modem for online multiplayer play; Network: TCP/IP compliant network

reviews.review_text: This is a long review, so if you just want a summary of why I recommend Dawn of War Gold Edition then skip to the  Results  section and reading from there.   Relic Entertainment works with Games Workshop to produce an epic real time strategy game that pushed the boundaries of the genre. Dawn of War offers economics, base building, military tactics, and unit management.    Story:  Dawn of War, the first installment on an incredible Warhammer 40,000 saga. The game is based on the planet Tarturus where Ork forces are out of control ravaging the planet and destroying Imperial Guard moral; but, how are they winning so easily? Of course the forces of Chaos are behind the whole war. Dawn of War is the story of Gabrial Angelos and Isador Akios and how they work together to figure out the whole reason behind the presence of Chaos on the imperial garrison at Tarturus.    Campaign:  The campaign offers an epic tale into the 40k lore with amazing twists and turns around every mission. Coupled with the amazing combat system, base management, and resource management this game really packs a punch. The campaign is divided into eleven missions which put you to the test fighting against the Orc Horde and the Chaos Might. As you progress through the campaign you work with the Eldar to defeat a common foe, but as the game dictates the Enemy of your Enemy is not always your friend. The game pits teams together, but at the same time continually draws them apart.    Gameplay:  This game was one of the first to successfully introduce rapid base expansion by requiring players to capture strategic points, which give the player a trickle of endless resources over time. The fast paced gameplay coupled with the macro and micro unit management really made this game a force to be reckoned with. Although the unit population seems rather low (20 personal – 10 vehicle) because the units are based in squads the real unit count is much higher. The battles seem more like full scale wars with you gripping to manage all your units at once. The best feature of this game (and all the Dawn of War games) is that each team is completely different. They have different units, different buildings, upgrades, tactics, resource types, hero units, and strategies. For example the Orc play completely different from the Eldar while both the Eldar and Orcs play completely different from the Space Marines and Chaos Marines. The only two similar teams are the Space Marines and Chaos marines which offer a good learners curve to Dawn of War by giving providing a basic approach to strategy: build barracks, build turrets for defense, use main base to upgrade to new “age” to receive better buildings, build power plants to get power, and upgrade units within armory, etc.    Teams:  There are four teams: Space Marines, Eldar, Orcs, and Chaos Marines. Each team poses different tactics/strategic elements which make you play them differently. The Orcs are based more around unit massing and rapid base expansion. While the Eldar are more about unit specialization and micro base management. The Space Marines and Chaos Marines are essentially the same team set, and fit between tactics of the Orcs and Eldar. Each of the teams units have upgradeable attributes which customize them for specific purposes: weapons, additional squad members, and squad leader units. Each team has special commander units which can be used as heroes buffing the team and supporting military units.   Results:  All and all Dawn of War is a must get game. If you can play older games without constantly yearning for the graphics of the modern day games then you’ll enjoy this game. The gameplay is not outdated, but rather refreshing. As it seems most strategy game developers have diverted from base building, resource management, and mass scale war to simple micromanagement tactic games. I loved this game and all the installments so much I repurchased them all on steam. Despite that I still have all the discs, in functional condition, right next to me.   Pros: +Economic, Base building, and macro unit management +Fantastic story and campaign (which is very rare in a strategy game) +Amazing teams which each play completely differently. +Fast paced gameplay which requires expansion to acquire resource nodes (but those nodes do not run out like in most games) +Unit customization allows you to create squads for specific tasks +Fantastic computer AI that puts you to your wits  Cons: -Cannot play this game while having another monitor running (if you have two monitors the game will launch but every time you move the mouse to the edge of the screen where your monitor extends the mouse exits the game as if you are playing in Windowed mode). -Lots of unbalances (don’t worry they fix all of these in the later installments)
Will die for the Emperor again & again.  40,000/10

I'm a huge RTS fan, but for whatever reason, I never picked this up until recently. I was introduced to the Warhammer 40,000 universe by way of the Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine third person shooter, which I greatly enjoyed. This universe has intrigued me since then, and I have tried to catch up with the more long-term fans of the franchise by reading up on the lore and such online. It's quite different from most fantasy; where magic and medieval type weaponry is common in fantasy, Warhammer has a refreshing spin on things, relying more on machinery and gunplay while keeping the magic and awe the fantasy genre offers to players. It also falls in the area of dystopian, which is by far my favorite genre of any entertainment, and it is interesting to have a protagonist in this game whose ideals and beliefs could be viewed as fanatical by our standards, but would be understandable in such a future where he serves beneath a totalitarian empire.  Moving on from the universe to the gameplay, Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War is an RTS that is unique in its approach to a genre that is tried and true. Whereas many RTS games focus on base building and annihilation, this game simplifies the base building and relies more on strategical points that you must capture for resource generation throughout the map. Each campaign or skirmish mission 'gets going', so-to-speak, much more quickly than other RTS games. You spend less time buiding and more time moving your armies along the map. For those that find some in the genre to be slow moving in the beginning, Dawn of War brings a welcome change.   Something else that Dawn of War does well that not enough RTS games do (sometimes at all) is reinforcements and upgrades. Where some games have you upgrade units from their respective recruitment centers and it encompasses all units of the same type, Dawn of War gives you more choice in how you want them upgraded. You can build a group of Space Marines, add reinforcements (making an initial group of four into up to eight), add sergeants later on, commanders, etc. In addition, with upgrades you can have a few men within the group upgrade their weapons, and the selection of weapons is up to you. You can have four rocket launchers, two rocket launchers, one flamethrower, and a laser pistol, or any combination between. This gives the player an ability to build up a small army for one intention (rocket launchers are great at taking out vehicles and buildings, for example), while creating another for a different intention (sending a differently equipped army to fight infantry). Even within firefights, you can reinforce your army if you possess the resources, giving the player a second chance in battle when most RTS games give none.  Lastly, it should be noted that I am a single player only strategy player, so I buy games like this for the campaign and skirmishes. In saying that, this game's campaign is fantastic. While somewhat short (eleven missions and about 15 hours of gameplay; note that Steam did not track all of my game time), the story is quite good and involving, taking you across many different types of landscapes and introducing you to different races to fight against. The cutscenes are a bit stilted due to the game's age, and the voice acting (while over-dramatic at times) is fantastic. The missions are vast and varied, and the game never gets in the habit of annoying you with time limits (I hate timed missions in any game, personally). The missions were challenging without being impossible, and they were friendly to both players who like to rush and complete the missions, and players like me, who like to leisurely explore the whole map and take over all positions before deciding to fully vanquish my enemy. Skirmishes are available, offering a few dozen maps that you can choose to play on, giving you choices as to what colors your army wears to which races you fight against, along with a whole myriad of other choices to make to tweak your gameplay if you so choose.   In summary, Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War is a fantastic RTS title that makes me very happy I purchased the Master Collection of games, because I am looking forward to experiencing more of this interesting universe. I would recommend it to any fans of RTS, as well as those looking to get into the genre, as this game is extraordinarily user friendly and has a fantastic tutorial. If you are unsure, I urge you to try the demo. I played the demo some time before buying the game and loved what it offered, so it is a fair representation of the game. I can see myself adding this to a list of games I come back to every now and then, because it offers a truly unique strategy experience that stands apart from others. I went into this game with no expectations other than what I'd read through some of the reviews, and after beating it, I consider myself a fan.

this game is up with starcraft 2 in my greatest rts games of all time with its extreme variety in the races and expansions that give you more races such as the massive imperial gaurd and the undead necrons i would buy this game and all its expansions it will be worth it

10/10. I played this masterpiece for the first time back in 2005 when my grandfather bought it for his 2003 E-machine. I played this game 24/7 for about 3 months until my Pops told me 'GET THE F**K OFF MY GAME!!!'... RIP Pops.
This game is great! For a game 10 years old, it still is a viable startegy game with comparable graphics, interesting units, and even a campaign that is decent.
My favorite RTS series of all time, a perfect game for any warhammer or sci fi lover
The story is just perfect awesome gury battles and epic voice ators big campaign and nice cutscreens

'WOW!' Is what I said to this game when I played it. This game in particular, excluding the Second Dawn Of War, is addicting, fun, down right amazing! I fell in love with this game at the moment I layed eye upon its beuty! The gameplay is really well rouned, the UI is pretty steady, the gameplay gives the 'mission accomplished and I'm a BADASS' feel. The Story is pretty interesting as you progress through it, there's no multiplayer due to GameSpy shutting down, but you can still setup a battle with the CPU, up to roughly 8 players, or 4v4 on a map. Definitely worth the payout! I give this game a 10/10. Just because it's old doesn't mean it sucks......well that's debateable, but still, GET IT !!!
We are the Emperor's chosen!

This game is really good if you like this kind of games. I have passed the whole game in 14.5h.  I will do some pros and cons for the game.  PROS -The game has a really cool campaign. 11 Missions long -The game has really good graphics -There are a lots of models for armies -Awesome soundtracks for this kinda game -This game has cheap trading cards -Community is alive after all this years -This game has not been forgotten, but it doesn't need any updates -There are some custom campaigns for the game on  moddb.com  but I never downloaded them myself -The story is really good in the game  CONS -The textures are blurred on buildings and army but not in a game world, I don't know if that problem occures only on my PC or not, only needed that Patch but everything else works fine -Multiplayer base is almost zero but there can be found some good matches. Found one so far and I loved it  I recommed this game. 9.5/10 would slaughter Orks again!

This game is a 40K fans dream. A RTS warhammer 40k game with all the iconic units and scenery you would expect find in the table top game. Totally recomend this game game to 40K fans and people just looking for a damn good game.
Ork Hunting SImulator 40K. Lose yourself in the thrill of the hunt! Do YOUR part for the galaxy at-large and help keep the Greenskin population within expected levels.  Zero.

Brand new player to the series (beyond Warhammer Online). With 3 new big titles (The MMO, The Space One, and the Total War One), I figured I should go back through for story and such.  No spoilers, but I'm several missions in; and enough to be caught up in the plot. The game is a bit aged in the graphics, but the story and action immerses you enough that you won't notice.  Unit controls and micro functions are lacking, but this is back in the day of 20 or 40 unit population limit, and 8 squads to a keybind. So.... they don't matter as much (because it's not thousands of units).  On the graphics front, turn on all those super fancy things your card does to the max!  If you bought that big pack, or bundle, this is the game I've been told to start with. Then just wiki the DLC/Expansion packs and play in order until 2!

Timeless classic, best 40k strategy game to date. It's annoying how you have to install each version of it to play all the races in multiplayer, but considerign how huge games are these days, it's not -that- big a problem, just an irritating one-time time-sink.  For those who don't know, you can also customize your army's badge and banner using 64x64 & 64x96 px .tga files. Do a bit of googling and enjoy!
One of the best strategy games in the last 10 years. Highly recommended
As a Warhammer 40k fan, this game is a must. We must do it for the Emperor.  10/10 awesomeness.  Do not let the Chaos influence you to do otherwise.
Pretty good RTS and the lore and units are just fascinating.

There's very little reason to pick this up instead of Dark Crusade nowadays--but this was the absolute ♥♥♥♥ back when it came out. It redefined the idea of what an RTS game could be and set Relic up as the best thing to happen to the genre not named Blizzard. ♥♥♥♥ was hot.

This RTS has aged very well. It differed greatly from other RTS at the time and is still a great game. This game focuses on the Space Marines fighting the Orks and Chaos with a little skirmish here and there with the Eldar. This game uses a squad based unit selection so 1-10 units move and fight with each other as an overall unit and take damage independently so as long as one member of the squad survives they can recover over time.

This is my lasgun. There are many like it, but this one is mine.   My lasgun is my best friend. It is my life. I must master it as I must master my life.   My lasgun, without me, is useless. Without my lasgun, I am useless. I must fire my lasgun true. I must shoot straighter than the heretic who is trying to kill me. I must shoot him before he shoots me. I will in the name of the God Emperor of Mankind...   My lasgun and I know that what counts in war is not the shots we fire, the noise of our screams, nor the corpse barricades we make. We know that it is the Immortal God Emperor of Mankind.    Before The Emperor, I swear this creed. My lasgun and I are the defenders of the Imperium of Man. We are the paving stones for the Adeptus Astartes. We are the joke of our enemy. We are the expendables of The Imperium.   So be it, until victory is The Emperor's and there is no enemy, but peace!
A nice addition to the Warhammer 40k world.
It's old, but is still a solid RTS.

A lot like Company of Heroes, just with 100% more Warhammer 40k.  I'm not a fan of the series but it's a great game in my opinion. I like to set up a base and crawl into my shell until I have a massive army.  Just don't play on Easy and expect fun...because it's REALLY REALLY easy.   Out of ten? Compared to other strategy games, probably about a 7 or 8/10. If it had more modern graphics and more interesting replayability, I would give it a 10/10, but since it was made a while ago, they're not to blame.   Jesus is.

An aging RTS gamey that, nevertheless, remains quite good. The plot is relatively straight-forward for 40k stuff: you fight lots of Orcs only to find that there is a greater danger lurking that the Space Marines, being the colossal ♥♥♥♥♥♥s that they are, unwittingly help out until the situation ends up becoming desperate. The plot is not particularly deep or complex, but it works alright.  Really the main reason to play this is to build huge armies of dudes and use them to kill tons of enemies for the glory of some emperor guy who probably is a jerk like many of his followers.  Anyway, have fun. :o
Origanally I didn't have it on Steam but then it made trouble on disk so I had to buy it on Steam. Anyway it is good.
Definitely an oldie but goodie RTS game. I don't have to play long to know I love it. Just wondering how I missed it all these years...

The Warhammer 40k series of games from Relic Entertainment is a series that never fails to let down, always capturing the feel of the tabletop game in a completely new fashion that is always fantastic, through the Dawn of War series of games and the third person shooter, Space Marine. Dawn of War 1 has a unique gameplay feel to it, as relic made the 2nd one also have a unique feel - giving this game a slot of originality that no other game, not even it's own sequel, is capable of matching. The voice acting, music, and storyline are superb not just by the standards of a real time strategy game but all games in general. And of course, there's the online or offline multiplayer on many maps, all custom made rather than campaign maps simply with redone start posistions and such.  This is a fantastic game that stands up to even modern day RTS games with no trouble. I highly recommend getting this game, whether you are a hardcore RTS fan or not much of one at all. It will deliver to everyone, and that is a promise.
Really amazing game that has now got me into the RTS genre. Definitely worth the money!!! I would say this has to be on my top 5 games now!

Still visually good looking game - Search for mods and you can add more races and units giving it more replay value (Ex. Titanium Wars mod lets you control titan machines, Chaos champions etc HOLY ♥♥♥♥ You'll just love it!) - Most gamers that have played the story missions will agree with me that Winter Assault's last mission is one of the best missions in RTS. Still remember that feeling of being overwhelmed by the enemy.  -Customize your army by naming them and warpaints  Cons - You are a heretic if you don't play this game. For the Emperor!!!

Dawn of War is Warhammer 40K's first Real-Time Strategy game in the collection of Warhammer 40K videogames. Since there's quite a bit to say, I'm just going to categorize the different sections of the game.  -Story: Combining aspects of fantasy and science fiction, you are tasked to lead Gabriel Angelos and the Space Marines known as the Blood Ravens as they take on a campaign to rid the planet of Tartarus of the war-loving, barbaric Orks. What first starts out as a quest of extermination becomes a more complex conflict as more hostile factions enter the fray and a threat that could endanger the whole galaxy is discovered. I will refrain from revealing much more about the story, but the campaign ends on a cliffhanger, all the more reason to buy DLC. While the campaign is only 11 missions long and feels paced a little faster than it probably should be, the game attempts to compensate with each level taking anywhere between 1-2.5 hours, which probably explains why the story may have been rushed. If you're a veteran of the RTS Genre, you may find the core game's campaign to be easy and manage to clear every level without failure. Overall it's a story that justifies your actions and explores a small fragment of what it's like to be part of the Imperium of Man if nothing else, but that doesn't make it any less enjoyable. 3.5/5  -Graphics: The game was made in 2004, as a result the graphics you're going to see are going to be a little dated in contrast to the more modern landscapes and character designs known today, even on the higher settings. As a result, the textures are going to be rather bland and lacking in detail in some places. Obvious geometry for the most part isn't too noticeable, however animations are rather rigid and limited and you will probably start seeing the same actions get repeated, especially during the Campaign cutscenes. Even with all the advancements in graphics throughout the years, Dawn of War ages surprisingly well. You'll be able to notice the bloodshed, corpses, bullet holes and explosion residue left in craters as the battles rage, even if there are a few limitations. The buildings are animated, so you'll know if your stuff is damaged, being built or whether something's happening, which is always useful in a fast-paced skirmish where information is vital. Every faction has their own distinct style that's present in their architecture and Game UI, preventing the player from confusing one side for another. Overall, the game's graphics aren't the best I've seen, but it's pretty remarkable considering what was available at the time. 4/5  -Gameplay: Dawn of War is one of the simpler RTS games in terms of complexity. The map is already drawn with every key point identified, however fog of war still exists, ensuring that reconnaissance is still important. There are only two resources to collect: Requisition and Power, with the former being automatically generated (but sped up as you explore the map and claim more points) and the latter requiring the player to construct generators to collect. Because of how requisition works, one never has to worry about the map being depleted of resources and being unable to build things, although it becomes much more difficult to construct anything when you have less buildings and points to generate resources. There are also few kinds of units, which allow for simpler yet fewer strategies. You will only encounter infantry, land vehicles and builders. Fortunately the game not only classifies infantry as groups that can be reinforced and improved with your resources wherever they're located, it also avoids adding defenseless builders when you attempt to select your army. There are four factions by default with more added in DLC, each promoting different strategies and play styles, but you're most likely going to be acquainted with the Jack of All Stat Space Marines from the campaign and the tutorial levels. Speaking of the tutorial, every key aspect playing the game is covered in an easy to understand way that will allow newcomers to at least figure out what they're supposed to be doing. One thing I will complain about is how limited the camera zooming is, as I tend to be unable to select all of my units that start occupying the entire screen, and at times your units may have difficulty simply going where you request them to, but not very often. Before I forget, there is one aspect that separates Dawn of War from other Real-Time Strategy games: Morale. Yes, the often mistakenly overlooked aspect of war that must be maintained within your ranks. Morale determines the survival of your units, and once its depleted they will start missing more often than a stormtrooper at point-blank range. Naturally there are commander units that exist to boost morale and/or break enemy spirit that can be bound to infantry squads and can prove to be dangerous units with enough research and training. Because of how morale works, it's never a good idea to send in a strike team that's outnumbered. To summarize everything that was just typed, Dawn of War is one of the less complex RTS games you'll find, but that doesn't make it necessarily easy or boring. 4/5  -Sound: Everything sounds like what you'd expect it to, weapons, vehicles and all. Each faction has their own idiosyncratic set of sound cues you'll associate them with. While it is a minor annoyance to hear your units make an announcement every single time something involving them changes, anything said will always be relevant to the given situation with examples such as “Squad broken!” and “Under fire!”. Everything your units say is not only standard, but reveals more of the personalities behind the unit type and the faction they hail from. The background music is usually faint compared to the action, which is a good thing in this case because it doesn't distract from the more important aspect of this game: Warfare. While the background music fits the scenario, there isn't much else to say about this limited track. Aside from the necessary announcements and some extra filler to avoid having the game sound too quiet, sound wasn't much of a focus on this game. 3.5/5  -Replayability: As games grow older and remain active through time, their replay value gradually diminishes and Dawn of War is no exception. While the campaign may keep one occupied anywhere between a few days to a week at most, there is no real incentive to play this game for very long. Skirmish mode may be fun for a few rounds to experiment with other factions and strategies, but aside from that there isn't much to say. While there might have been an active multiplayer for the core game in the past, hardly anyone tends to roam the lobbies anymore. Unless you know of other people who own the core game, you may end up never setting foot in the multiplayer community. Fortunately there are three DLC expansion packs that can add more vitality for the game, with the majority of them being well-received as they incorporate new factions, campaigns and possibly fixes to whatever bugs exist and updates for the graphics. With what little exists in the core game, DLC is practically a necessity, although it's important to keep in mind that Dawn of War has a sequel where the majority of users have most likely migrated to. A little distressing, but what do you expect from an old game? It's a miracle it's still even active. 3.5/5  Summary/TL;DR:  Dawn of War may not be the most complex Real-Time Strategy game out there, but that doesn't make it any less fun. Overall score: 18.5/25 or 74%*  *Note: This score is for the core game itself. The expansion packs have not been evaluated by this user and may change the score.

I have only played the tutorial (1Hour) and i'm already in love with this game. If you have to choose from this one or dawn of war 2. Pick this one for base building or pick DOW2 for a game more like company of heros. right now from playing the tutorial i give it a solid 9/10

There are a lot of RTS games out there and Dawn of War is one of the best of the best. It actually does feel like you're playing the Warhammer 40K tabletop game, except without all of the hassle. While the graphics are lacking nowadays, the gameplay and fun factor are still top-notch. There is base building, but it doesn't require an insane amount of micro-managing like SC2 does, for example. What makes this game so enjoyable to me is that you spend the majority of your time managing your massive army and it's just straight up fun to do.  The campaign is OK and worth a single playthrough. Just be prepared for drawn out conversations, overly wordy narration, and some incredibly terrible voice acting (though it does have a particular charm). The meat and potatoes is the multiplayer mode, which you can play against CPU bots or online. In this version of the game you can pick between four factions which include Space Marines, Orks, Eldar and Chaos.  Highly recommended.
Admit it, you like to sacrifice your virginity to the Emperor.
It's chronic

This game is a blast from the past. This was one of my favourite RTS game in my childhood, back when I didn't know what an RTS was. This game has good graphics, runs smooth and has a lot of content. The storyline on hard for me took 10 hours and I enjoyed every second, beautiful mission designs and very good storyline. Lots of different troops and buildings. When I finished the game I said to myself “I have to buy dawn of war2'because of how much fun I had playing it and wanted to know what happens in the storyline.10/10 must buy on sale.

A great game and very fun. It takes me back as I remember playing Warhammer 40k as a kid since I had no group of friends who enjoyed dungeon mastering. Many of the units are very memorable of that past time and the story of this is one-sided (unlike the expansions) though memorable. It will suck you in though and hours will go by without knowing it.
One of the finest RTS games ever made! Burn the Heretic!!!
its the best stragety game ive played in a long time
its a very nice game :)

What can I say, accept that this game is awesome! 40k is best served as an RTS, even though I think they are heading towards a MOBA style after Dawn of War II gameplay style and Renicide.....at least as rumor has it :P  Just going to jump right into it:  PROS  You can make your owqn faction Ok graphics Great Music Can be used on lower-end computers (I have a higher end and a lower end) With friends to play with = Amazing! ...even vs AI comps Price is great for all the fun possible  CONS  Can't change Population max without a MOD Community Online is quite dead (Also a few private with pass rq games) Units when under crtl+# do not act as intelligent as they could when staying together.  MISC  Does not follow Warhammer Table-top 100% in damage distribution and armor, but close enough   All-in-all a great all around game. Even though it does not follow the rules of the real codex and mechanical understandings of weapons to armor, it does a great job all the same. So if you love RTS this one is a bit different, but still an RTS to add to your collection. If you love Warhammer Space Marine 40,000 then probably don't have to suggest this to you because you probably already own this... Basically a must buy to add to your Steam collection, even if just for solo skirmish mode. You can also use this game to help you understand how the online 40k applies damage to certain armors and special abilities; which are somewhat different than table top, but seem to be reoccurring throughout 40k online games.   Sirspoony's rating = 8.25/10 8.75 to 9/10 if community was not so dead

I played the original game when it came out and enjoyed it a lot. Bought it on Steam to relive the glory but unfortunately can't recommend it. Too many problems with sound cutting out. I'm not shy about going on forums and searching for and implimenting fixes but the sound issues, like low-volume, static, or missing sounds pop up every other session. Gimme a break!   Playing on an office commercial Dell with Win 7 but the box is over ten years younger than the game; one of the reasons i chose to install it here. It shouldn't be this much of a problem.

A good old-fashioned RTS set in the Warhammer 40k universe. Runs smoothly, easy to learn but hard to master, looks pretty good for an older game, engaging story mode and addicting co-op/ai mode. I wish more people were on the online multiplayer, but I'm happy popping on to play an hour-long game against a bunch of bots. My friend and I once had a 6-hour long game with us on a team against multiple teams of hard bots.   Recommend for anybody who likes RTS games, but not for the whiney newer generation of gamers who think anything without triple-a cutting edge graphics is bad.

At this point, I could honestly only suggest this game to hardcore RTS fans, specifically those who are into WarCraft 3 but could expand into some new lore and mechanics. It's just aged a great deal. It looks and feels bad. The soundtrack seems on par with the sequels though, and there seems to be plenty of story in the campaign, and a neat territorial conquest theme to the campaign that the DoW2 series did not have.  Now, I'm typically not a fan of true RTS games, which might be why I feel like Dawn of War 2 was a vastly superior set of games in ALL ways, but I can understand that the first Dawn of War series of content here can hold some people's attention. They're definitely more focused on more multitasking and bigger squadrons. That kind of stuff honestly just hurts my brain. I much prefer DoW2's 4-Hero Unit campaign structure, and it's Last Stand mode (though now largely unplayed).  As far as multiplayer goes, I cannot comment, as I know my role there. I am no use to any team. That's probably where this first series shines, from what I hear.

this game is pretty good, but i feel that what bored me mot was the slow pace of the game, RTSs are now on a whole new level, and honestly you can feel the age in this game, for one who likes the Warhammer 40k story, this game would be perfect

Dates. So very dated. I played this based on a friends reccomendation. Walked away confused about how much he enjoyed himself....but then it hit me. This is one of those titles that survives off of nostalgia. Keep that in mind!

Dated mechanically, technically, graphically, the game is a joke only Warhammer fans could like. Completely unjustified metacritic score. I like the 40k universe. I don't like 'the worst AI pathfinding you've ever experienced,' micro-micro management, among more nonsense you could expect from an old mainstream rts.  Don't listen to the jokers telling you anything otherwise. Play the apocalypse one. It's turn based and simpler graphically, but it's a game... that works.

The game itself is a fun RTS, but the issues hold it back for me. I've tried it on multiple computers since I bought it a few years ago, and I can't get more than halfway through a mission without it crashing on me. A huge disappointment, since the little bit of time I've managed to play it was good. It doesn't have widescreen support built in (there's a fan-made patch to add it, but it's still not perfect), but I honestly enjoyed it enough (again, while it worked) not to mind black borders on the sides of my screen.  Since so many other people have had it run fine for them, it's almost definitely something about the computers I've tried playing it on. Don't spend a cent on it unless you know for certain it works on your computer (try the demo first!).  I only have half an hour listed because I only added it to Steam hoping they had fixed the issues in the newest patches. It's still crashing as often as it did when I installed it from my boxed copy.
I could not continue the tutorial because my keyboard does not have 'Home' key, and the numpad didn't work.
Never enjoyed this style of game.
Amazing cheap game, would recommend buying it on sales
this is one of the most amazing games ive ever played by far my absolute favorite this game has good mechanics

This is a great game for new and veteran rts players alike. It teaches the fundamentals of RTS video games to the letter, ensuring you understand a unit, what it is effective against, what it is weak to and keeping your army upgraded is a constant factor in this game. Assuming you have the requisition points and energy to do so. On a deeper level, the game has a long lasting and incredibly unique and original story that has turned me into a die hard Warhammer 40K. I reccomend this to all RTS players who want a challenging, fun and immersive game. For the Emperor. For the Imperium!
one of the best game i have ever played

A must play for EVERY RTS fan. Gorgeous artstyle, macro managing, quick base expansion, good sense of screen filled of soldiers, every race changes drastically and fit plethora of game styles and strategies, nice dark sci fi ambience and fast paced gameplay.  Essential RTS game for both fans of the genre and W40k fans.

Dawn of War is still just as amazing as you remember it being. The campaign is a blast to play and the multiplayer support from Steam is awesome. Though the expansions to this, the first game of the franchise make it progressively better, it is well worth the time to revisit this classic.  Graphics - 7/10 For its time the graphics were solid, though this is the one aspect of the game I would say hasn't aged well. Still very passable, and looks alright when zoomed out.  Gameplay - 9/10 Soulstorm is where it's at if you are looking for multi, but the campaign of the initial release is still a lot of fun.  Sound - 7/10 The voice acting was a nice inclusion, and imparted the story effectively. Some of the sound effects had a hollow tinny ring to them however.  Dev Support - 11/10 I think it is simply awesome how commited Relic is to continued support of the titles of this franchise. They may be a bit older, but the quality has not diminished with age. They are doing their best to make sure that the Steam version works with mods, and that we all can continue to enjoy head-to-head play.
My Gateway Drug to RTS Games.

This is a great game for new and veteran rts players alike. It teaches the fundamentals of RTS video games to the letter, ensuring you understand a unit, what it is effective against, what it is weak to and keeping your army upgraded is a constant factor in this game. Assuming you have the requisition points and energy to do so. On a deeper level, the game has a long lasting and incredibly unique and original story that has turned me into a die hard Warhammer 40K. I reccomend this to all RTS players who want a challenging, fun and immersive game. For the Emperor. For the Imperium!

Dawn of War has always been a favorite of mine and I was saddened when gamespy closed the servers, but Steam has delieverd on it fully. With all of the patches included when you buy the game and with excellent replayability and access to multiplayer, this game is well worth the buy.  For those of you new to the series, you can expect a fun RTS game set in the Warhammer 40k universe, with several play styles and races avaiable to you with the Vanilla purchase, and with more available as expansions are bought, you will find a diverse group of races and strategies at your disposal, with a dedicated, albiet small group of modders and other players along side you.   In short, if you have the funds and are looking for a fun time, buy this game, its well worth it

I've ONLY played the single-player campaign and it was very enjoyable. The campaign has a very good story that borrows a lot from the actual WH franchise, so those familiar with the Space Marines should have a lot to look forward too. The plot's fleshed out by interesting and some what lengthy cutscenes before and after each mission. The voice actors in the game are very over the top and sometimes cheesy, but they manage to fit each character well and the voice acting actually comes away as a very bright spot in the game for me.  Game-play wise there isn't a whole lot of 'new' here compared to other RTS games, but what is included is polished. For its release date I consider the game to be very technically capable with things like decent character animations and solid over-all performance. Fans of RTS games or the Warhammer franchise should definitely give this one a shot.

I'm not a huge RTS fan (that is to say, I like 'em, but I suck at 'em, :-), but I really liked some of the things they did in this game to enhance tactical gameplay (as opposed to just the 'BUILD ALL THE THINGS, KILL ALL THE THINGS!' approach used in AoEII and other games. Units come in squads, you can resupply squads in the field, units shoot without you having to tell them to shoot, capture points, attaching heroes and healers to squads, upgrading. This all made it feel different and exciting and also very much like a Warhammer 40k game (Not a big 40k fan, but WH Fantasy fan, definitely).  The story is ♥♥♥♥, the voice acting atrocious, but the gameplay makes up for that. I do have to say I only played the singleplayer campaign (I'm not really into skirmishes and definitely no MP). I liked the inclusion of an Army Painter option in the menu.  Will definitely play some expansions and looking forward to DoW2.
Would I recommend this game? Yes; yes I would. It is one of thee best if not THE best Warhammer 40k RTS games out there.

If you like Sci Fi and starwars and RTS and stuff like then you will love this game...its got Space Marines what more can a mortal ask for ? lol And remember Death to the enemys of the Emperor !! Also its a solid entertaining game with lots of differnt classes and races so im sure youll find somthing to like about this game :) proper old school game :)

Dawn of War is an excellent strategy game, and a must-have for fans of the Warhammer 40,000 franchise. The campaign is solid, the multiplayer and skirmish modes are excellent, and--barring Soulstorm--the expansions are top-notch. Sure, the voice-acting can be corny at times, but then that's part of the game's charm.   It's by no means perfect. The AI sometimes has pathing issues, and on occasion there are times were the campaign makes odd choices with some of your units (such as putting the Whirlwind artillery tanks in the Cease Fire stance by default). And of course, there is the mess that is Soulstorm. Even so, I found the game immensely enjoyable for the most part, both as a fan of Warhammer 40k and as a fan of strategy games.

D.O.W. 40k GOTY is the 1st RTS game that got me into the genre. These games are so amazing and the tutorials make it easily accessible with easy to follow instructions and info on how to command units and supply resources. I also highly reccomend company of heroes 1 and 2 a WWII RTS. Another GAMES WORKSHOP thq developed game wich is highly acclaimed as one of the highest rated RTS's of all time! I love these type of games as im am huge sci-fi and fantasy NERD and this has both. I have been so burnt out with the FPS and same old fantasy rpg story genre 'generic' these last few years 12,13, that i decided to try out a different genre and im glad i did cause theres a lot of great games in this genre and warhammer 40k has a lot of them. Its not the best looking game but it is 7 years old now and i think it holds up well. the gameplay is still great and is what got me hooked on 40k and RTS games. its extremely fun and immersive i just love this universe and have already purchused some of the books. I give D.O.W. GOTY edition a 9.25/10. for its time a great game!

Fantastic RTS, the campaign is great and has an interesting story. Once you're done with the campaign you can hop into the multiplayer, most fun multiplayer experience I've had in a while.  Overall, awesome game but not worth $20.00, definitely get it if it goes on sale though.

Being a fan of strategy games in genral I thought this game was great and I found it to be a lot of fun.

The only other Warhammer 40k strategy game I can recall playing was Final Liberation way back in the day (unless you want to count Space Hulk on both the 3DO and PS3, tho that was more FPS than RTS I'd say). This game makes me wonder why I haven't played more. All fans of RTS should give this one a shot. There's a good variety of units, base building isn't a grind, and the Warhammer series IMHO has THE BEST balance of any strategy games I've ever played. You get into the action quickly and new units are introduced pretty much as soon as you're ready for them.   I'll put this one up against Starcraft (which I feel is a good benchmark for RTS games) any day of the week. My only recommendation would be to get the expansion packs too if you can. The campaign is 11 missions long and seemed to go by too quickly to me. However, that may have been because I enjoyed the game so much.

The biggest selling points for me: Warhammer 40k aesthetics, paired with Relic's well-known, and quite functional mechanics. Even for a game that's kicking down the door on a decade worth of age, it still looks decent enough, and plays very well. Outside of that, the single player campaign provides an interesting backstory, though I honestly don't know enough about 40k lore to be able to pick up on whether everyone is canon, or if there's some weirdness involved.
The game that started it all... feels hollow without the expansions so don't skimp, get em all and do not fret, for fear denies faith.
it wus cool.

Fun enough RTS, really let's you get into the nitty-gritty of things. Not very lore intensive for the Warhammer 40k Universe so don't expect to much out of it in terms of story and dialouge. That aside I have had a lot of fun on multiplayer and inserting my own dialouge into the campaign mode. Don't be fooled byt the 'Game of the Year Edition' title this is just the basic game with multiplayer functionality. Holds no actually DLC.

Unique Strategy Title which offers deep environment perfect for serious law-friendly battles (to an extent). Campaign which allows players to develop strategies to later use in multiplayer skirmishes.
